data.bio: Born into slavery in Ulster county, New York, but escaped with her daughter to freedom in 1826. Her best-known extemporaneous speech on gender inequalities, "Ain't I a Woman?", was delivered in 1851 at the Ohio Women's Rights Convention in Akron, Ohio.
data.name: Sojour Truth

data.bio: On December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks sparked a pivoting point in US History when she refused to obey bus a driver's order that she give up her seat in the colored section to a white passenger.
data.name: Rosa Parks

data.bio: Elizabeth II has quietly become one of the longest-reigning monarchs in English history. In addition, Elizabeth II has started new trends toward modernization and openness in the royal family.
data.name: Queen Elizabeth II

data.bio: On June 18, 1983 Sally Ride became the first American woman in space aboard the space shuttle Challenger. As a mission specialist, she helped deploy satellites and worked other projects.
data.name: Sally Ride

data.bio: Austrian actress who became a pioneer in the field of wireless communication following her emigration to the United States.Helped develop a secret communication system to help combat the Nazis
data.name: Hedy Lamarr

data.bio: Chanel was raised in orphanages where she was taught to sew. She had a brief career as a singer before opening her first clothes shop in 1910. In the 1920s she becameone of 20th centuries best knows fashion desingers.
data.name: Coco Chanel

data.bio: Award winning television news reporter, she is considered one of today's leading news correspondents. Christiane Amanpour has covered many of the world's most dangerous conflicts and devastating events.
data.name: Christian Amanpour

data.bio: Betty Ford was known both as a former First Lady and as the founder of the Betty Ford Clinic for substance abuse recovery.
data.role: First Lady of the United States
data.name: Betty Ford

data.bio: Marie Curie became the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the only woman to win the award in two different fields (physics and chemistry). Curie's efforts led to the discovery of polonium and radium and, the development of X-ray.
data.name: Marie Curie

data.bio: Biologist Rachel Carson alerted the world to the environmental impact of fertilizers and pesticides. Her best-known book, Silent Spring, led to a presidential commission that largely endorsed her findings and helped to shape a growing environmental consciousness.
data.name: Rachel Carson

data.bio: Graham is called the Mother of Modern Dance. She was a dancer, choreographer, and teacher for more than 70 years, and during that time she changed the landscape of dance forever. An unlikely candidate for a dance diva, she was shorter and more muscular than the principal ballet dancers of her time.
data.name: Martha Grahm

data.bio: Know as the ancient world's most famous mathematician, philosopher, and astronomer.
data.name: Hypatia

data.bio: First woman in show business to own a film studio.
data.name: Lucille Ball

data.role: Queen consort of Jordan as the wife of King Abdullah II of Jordan.
data.name: Queen Rania of Jordan

data.bio: American TV chef and author, Julia Child adapted sophisticated French cuisine for mainstream Americans, she collaborated on a two-volume cookbook called Mastering the Art of French Cooking, which was considered groundbreaking.
data.name: Julia Child

data.bio: Nancy Reagan is a former first lady of the United States. She served as first lady of California before moving into the White House. Her major initiative was the "Just Say No" drug awareness campaign.
data.role: First Lady of the United States
data.name: Nancy Reagan

data.role: British Politician and Former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
data.name: Margaret Thatcher

data.bio: As First Lady, writer, and humanitarian, Eleanor was one of the most outspoken women in the White House. She carried a strong dedication to social and civic issues of her time.
data.role: First Lady of the United States
data.name: Eleanor Roosevelt
